subject: RE: [junit] Management wants to know ...
msgSnippet: It s fairly objective, as far as I can tell.  I tend to is no such thing as too much testing -- in other words, if you have the time and man-power test until
messageBody:
It's fairly objective, as far as I can tell. I tend to is no such thing
as too much testing -- in other words, if you have the time and
man-power test until you can test no more. I measure too little testing
by several factors:
1. inability to refactor, redesign, etc.
2. lack of confidence that what I am doing isn't breaking something
without my knowing
3. number of unresolved bugs (which I treat as test cases that have yet
to be written)
4. level of brittleness in the code (related to #2)
5. etc. (someone else chime in)

=jason
[:question | ^One]
-----Original Message-----
From: tumb@... [mailto:tumb@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 18, 2003 3:13 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Management wants to know ...



Is there any recommended (or better yet documented) ideal level of
testing?
Our company is working on adopting XP and perhaps test driven practises.
We have a question about whether certain groups are testing too little
or
too much. How, if at all, do you determine what's too little or too
much?
